Bob's Burgers is a great animated series that's more family-friendly and upbeat. It's all about a family going through the oddness of everyday life and trying to run their restaurant as best they can.
There's also an online mini-series called "Smart Guys" where three buddies are trying to make their own video game without any background education in the subject matter. Pretty funny and a bit exaggerated surrealism.

Jessica Jones - I felt like it had three very solid beginning episodes, then lost its mind completely. Things like not actually knowing how the legal system works on a basic level, the annoyance of side-stories that go nowhere, the whole thing with "Nuke" (seriously, that's stretching the level of coincidence I'm willing to accept), side stories that have no actual relevance to the rest of the series (like Luke's wife and the flash drive), questions that aren't at all answered or touched upon (like why Jessica was able to break free of Kilgrave's control or how she even got her powers).
The actings all over the place, the characters are too broadly written, side steps interesting issues they could have taken the story down, and has a main protagonist who actively discourages liking or siding with her.
I usually think it's a solid show, but I LOATHED season/series 8.

We've already established that Atheism is "a lack of belief in gods or god"
There's a difference between "disbelief in God(s)" and "belief that there are no Gods". The first would be closer to agnosticism, whereas the second is a held belief there aren't any God(s) which would be atheism.
which is not a belief system because the definition of Atheism is explicitly a lack of belief nothing more.
No, because even if atheism was defined as a "non-belief in a God", it's still presupposing other philosophical assumptions, which have already been mentioned in the "Scandinavian Skeptic" above. Even if you change the definition of "belief that there are no Gods" to "non-belief in God(s)", it's STILL a belief.
So calling Atheism a belief system would be like calling lacking a hobby a type of hobby.
No, calling atheism a belief system would be like calling abstinence a position on sexual activity, as in, one knows about it, and one chooses not to engage in it.
Allow me to pull up another argument from "the Scandinavian Skeptic":
A further drastic problem arises if the atheist wishes to claim that his statement there is no God is not a claim or a beliefif it isnt, then it cannot be true or false. The problem is that only claims can be true or false. It makes perfect sense to ask whether a claim like It is raining today or The Maple Leafs lost again is true or false. On the other hand, it is meaningless to ask whether the colour blue, a small off-duty Czechoslovakian traffic warden, or the word Wibble are truethey are not claims and thus cannot possess a truth value. So heres the problem for the atheist. If atheism is not a claim of any kind, then it is simply meaningless. On the other hand, if the atheist wishes to claim that his atheism is true, then that must mean that atheism is a claim, and claims need to be defended, evidence provided and reasons given.

Regardless your claim that Atheism is an ideology that started this conservation is absolutely and entirely false.
I do concede that I shouldn't have placed that word in association with atheism itself, but I should have made it more clear that it was used in context of the Soviet Union's political doctrines and ethics utilizing atheism.
It's not a belief system because Atheism is simply a lack of belief in god(s) thus you don't believe in anything.
You put forth positive claims by the very argument "atheism is a non-belief", which you've STILL yet to argue against.

No. It is not a belief system, Atheists refuse to admit that because unlike you they understand their lack of belief is not a belief system.
Basically, your argument is boiled down to "it isn't a belief system, because I don't want it to be" rather than arguing WHY it isn't.
I also noticed you failed to actually address the criticisms brought forth by the "Scandinavian Skeptic" article.
Which game is this?

Atheism is the concept of not believing in God and is not intrinsically tied to communism as many Americans STILL think decades after the fall of the Soviets.
Yes, it is. Especially since it has been the governmental doctrine that has been violently enforced across many communist countries. The Soviet Union, Mao's China, and Pot's Cambodia violently oppressed religious peoples and institutions. Marxism-Lenism, Maoism, and Stalinism all employed actively oppressing the religious (to the point of active genocide), justified their oppression through their dedication to atheism/state-secuarlism, and promoted atheism/state-secularism.
The Soviets DID subscribe to atheism as a defining part of their ideology, and used it to be [hostile towards the religious](http://www.country-data.com/cgi-bin/query/r-12521.html). No, that doesn't mean that being atheistic makes you a violent oppressor. My point is that they used that belief as apart of their ideology, and twisted it for their own ends.

it's a lack of belief in god(s) that's it.
Okay. I sincerely believe that atheism is a belief system (which doesn't inherently make it a weaker argument, and I think that atheists are strangely afraid of acknowledging the idea that it's a belief system out of some irrational fear that it somehow undermines their argument to understand that their position is an abstract notion based on their own arguments and evidence).
Communists =/= Atheists,
I understand that sentiment; I know they're not the same thing. That's not my argument. My point is that Communism utilized atheism in their political doctrines and programs and used the belief of atheism to justify their prejudice against the religious. No, it doesn't mean that being atheist makes you prejudiced against those who are religious/spiritual to the point of violent action. What I'm saying is that they warped an ideology to allow themselves to persecute others. It could have been any other ideology, and in this case, it was atheism, like it was nationalism with the Nazis or religion with the Muslims during the crusades.
all communists may be atheists but not all atheists
I agree. I was merely pointing out that communist countries like the Soviet Union, Mao's China, or Cambodia under Pot used demanded that atheism be the state "religion", and that all other religions were to be violently oppressed in favor of making the people subscribe to that ideology.
Just because atheism is a part of communist ideology does not mean that it's an ideology,
Atheism is an ideology, because it's an active belief. If someone says "I don't know if there are any Gods" that's agnostic. Maybe if they say "I'm leaning towards there not being any Gods, but I'm certain enough to say I don't believe in any Gods" that's agnostic atheist (at best). If you know what God's are, and you say you don't believe in them, that's not a passive belief. That is an active claim. It's the belief that there are no Gods.
I really would suggest you read the article "[The Scandinavian Skeptic](http://www.rzim.eu/the-scandanavian-sceptic-or-why-atheism-is-a-belief-system)" (as I had linked above) to why it is a belief and how it's intellectually dishonest to not consider it one (which is, to say, that atheism as a belief does not lessen it's arguments as a belief). As "The Scandanavian Skeptic" points out, just by claiming that "atheism is just non-belief in God(s)":
The atheist is now claiming to believe that the external world really exists (thus she is rejecting metaphysical idealism), that other minds exist, that the human mind can form beliefs, and that our cognitive faculties are broadly reliable. Each of those is a hotly debated area in philosophy.
Even claiming it's a "non-belief" (which I wouldn't classify atheism as) brings positive claims to the table.
Their ideology (which wasn't Atheism) is what was used to justify their violence against religion/religious people.
Their ideology was based on militant atheism, and active government-sponsored programs to re-educate the masses to distrust and vilify religion; they actively imprisoned the religious in gulags and utilized executions for those holding religious beliefs. Yes, it's only part of their ideology, and throwing in atheism doesn't make something inherently worse or holding to the idea that atheism will immediately make you a bad person, but they used atheism as apart of their governmental doctrine, and used that militant form of the ideology as justification for their persecution of the religious (specifically the Christians in their country).
